author: sky.cactus
content: I think what you want is a forum like Ethereum Magicians or Ethereum Research.  IMO, chat shouldn't be expected to be persistent.

author: sky.cactus
content: When I'm championing an EIP, I always try to summarize discussion into a post on the discussions-to link of the EIP.  That way people don't have to read a lengthy chat or have access to Discord.

author: sky.cactus
content: Similar to how if I had a discussion in-person or via voice call I would summarize the outcomes of that into a more permanent and searchable location.

author: gcolvin
content: The trouble is that a lot more than chat happens here.  Serious discussions happen here, and there is no other record.  Gitter had its problems, but when people asked why decisions were made - including people on core devs calls - we could link back to the relevant discussions there.

author: sky.cactus
content:
> and there is no other record
I think this is the core of the problem.  Anytime serious discussion happens here and decisions are made the discussion **_should_** be summarized and the conclusions described in a more permanent location.

author: sky.cactus
content: If people are having discussions here and *not* propagating that information to more permanent sources I think that is bad.  The same is true for traditional businesses where in-person discussions **should** be summarized and recorded somewhere more permanent than a verbal conversation (which is incredibly transient).

author: sky.cactus
content: I don't think the solution in the traditional world is to record all voice conversations, it is to follow the practice of recording summaries.

author: gcolvin
content: What tends to happen is that on allcoredev calls there is a small amount of discussion and decisions are made that ratify consensus already achieved in discussions on the allcoredevs channel.  Without a way to refer back to these discussions it's not clear how consensus was achieved.  And without a way for people to easily follow these discussions we get accused of blindsiding people with our decisions.

author: gcolvin
content: Email worked.  Usenet worked.  IRC worked.  Standard protocols, lots of servers and archives, clients with whatever UX you preferred.  Now we have proprietary protocols and I'm forced to learn a new UX every few months and use five or six of them every day that don't connect to each other.  50 years and no real progress.  But I'm a whiny old man ...
